DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US trade negotiators are reportedly likely to visit China next week for first face-to-face meeting since the G20, according to sources. Furthermore, the report added that talks to reach a deal to end the trade war are still expected to take a significant amount of time and that the initial arrangements for the meeting in Beijing came after the US announced it would offer exemptions to 110 Chinese products earlier this month. (Newswires)

BoJ's Kuroda said it is not easy to continue powerful measures for a long time and that powerful monetary easing has boosted demand by lowering real interest rates although it is taking time to overcome low inflation. Kuroda warned on the risks of prolonged low interest rates where banks could become less profitable and reduce lending but he does not think this risk is currently showing in Japan, while he also noted that with zero lower bound for short-term interest rates, it might be better to directly affect long-term rates through large-scale asset purchases. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

A cross-party group of MPs and peers is seeking a ruling in Scotland’s Court of Session to ensure the next PM cannot suspend parliament to force through a no-deal Brexit. (Independent)

UK House Speaker Bercow turned down Sir Alan Duncan's request for an emergency vote tomorrow following the announcement of the new PM to test if a majority can be held, according to BBC's Political Editor Kuenssberg. (Twitter/BBC)

Labour peers decided not to hold vote of no confidence in Jeremy Corbyn. (Politics Home)

Irish Foreign Minister Covaney reiterated hope that the incoming UK PM can take an innovative approach to the declaration on the future relationship and that the EU withdrawal agreement is fair, balanced and is not going to change. (Newswires)

UK Trade Secretary Fox said the new PM and Cabinet may take a different view on the No Deal tariff schedule published in March and said "they can be changed" as a warning to Canada that “the worst happens and we introduce trade frictions”, according to BBC’s Faisal Islam. Faisal Islam also tweeted that several US Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee raised the potential blocking of a US-UK trade deal to UK Trade Secretary Fox if Brexit saw a hardening of Irish border or impact on the Good Friday agreement. (Twitter/BBC)

 

GEOPOLITICS

UK Foreign Minister Hunt said Iran had no right to board the UK vessel which was an act of piracy and urged Iran to release the vessel and its crew. Hunt added that there is no comparison between seizure of the tanker and EU sanctions. Hunt added UK will seek to put together a European led maritime mission as well as compliment US proposals in the area of maritime security, while he also suggested that if Iran continues on this dangerous path they must accept the price of a larger western military presence along their coastline. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he is going to sit back and wait with regards to Iran and reiterated ‘we’ll see what happens’, while he added it is getting harder for him to make a deal and that it could go either way very easily. (Newswires)

US imposed sanctions on Chinese company Zhuhai Zhenrong for transporting Iranian crude oil. (WSJ) 

 

US

US President Trump tweeted that with almost no inflation, the US is needlessly being forced to pay a much higher interest rate than other countries only because of a very misguided Federal Reserve and that quantitative tightening is continuing to make it harder for the US to compete. Furthermore, Trump reiterated that interest rate costs should have been much lower and that it is very unfair that other countries manipulate their currencies and pump money in. (Twitter)

 

MARKET RECAP

Tech was the outperforming sector on Monday, as chipmakers rallied as White House officials agreed to meet tech executives regarding the recent Huawei ban. Applied Materials Inc. (AMAT), Micron Technology (MU), Lam Research (LRCX) and KLA-Tencor Corp. (KLAC) all caught a bid after Goldman turned positive on memory chip makers helping the tech sector, too. Facebook (FB) shares were supported initially by positive comments at Wedbush and saw further upside later in the session on reports the co. had agreed to a USD 5bn FTC settlement, a better outcome than some investors had feared. Meanwhile, Amazon (AMZN) was supported by a sizeable PT raise at KeyBanc and Apple (AAPL) supported by positive comments from Morgan Stanley ahead of earnings.  Elsewhere, Disney (DIS) was buoyant, after its live action remake of the Lion King exceeded expectations over the weekend. Ford (F) were weighed by reports sales in China will fall 27% in H2 2019 Y/Y, amid a downturn in the Chinese car market. AT&T (T) and CBS Corp (CBS) were both under pressure on news that the two companies failed to renew their contract, which will see millions of DirecTV subscribers lose access to CBS programmes. DaVita Inc. (DVA) shot higher after the co. raised its FY19 operating guidance. Bunge Ltd (BG) moved higher premarket on the news the co. has agreed to form a new bioenergy company with BP Plc (BP LN), which will produce ethanol and sugar, while also generating renewable electricity. Notable stocks benefitting after positive broker moves; Charles Schwab (SCHW) upgraded at Well Fargo, Hershey (HSY) upgraded at UBS. Notable stocks suffering after broker downgrades; Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) downgraded at Citi, LyondellBasell (LYB) downgraded at Nomura Instinet, M&T Bank (MTB) downgraded at Piper Jaffray. It was a thin day for large cap earnings; Halliburton Co. (HAL) shot higher after exceeding bottom-line expectations. S&P 500 0.3% at 2985, NASDAQ-10 0.9% at 7905, Dow Jones 0.1% at 27173.

The T-plex ultimately edged higher on Monday, as participants tread carefully ahead of Thursday’s ECB meeting, where speculation is rife on when and how the ECB will provide monetary accommodation. Some constructive headlines from China over the weekend, who reportedly made goodwill gestures in trade negotiations, saw some mild pressure in government debt in the early session, but was later reversed as traders bought the dip. Bidding pressure was complimented by a surprise dip in the Chicago Fed June National Index -0.02 (exp. 0.08), as well as the overhang of geopolitics. At settlement yields were modestly negative, with the belly seeing the most pronounced action, the 5-year yield fell by just under 2bps. US T-note futures (U9) settled 2 ticks higher at 127-19.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 22nd July 2019: Tech leads stocks higher as US & China agree to face-to-face talks
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries flat/up, dollar up, crude up.
  • REAR VIEW: US negotiators likely to visit China next week; UK threatens greater “western” military presence in the Gulf;
  • COMING UP: Data; US Existing Home Sales, US API Crude Stocks, NZ Trade Balance, Events; Hungarian Rate Decision, Speakers; BoE’s Haldane, Spanish PM Sanchez, Auctions; UK 2029 Gilt, US 2yr Note, Earnings from; Lockheed Martin, AMD, Biogen, Chubb, Discover Financial, Hasbro, Harley-Davidson, Kimberly Clark, Coca-Cola, Visa, United Technologies, Santander, ASM, UBS, Lindt & Spruengli.

 

* MARKET WRAP: Equites moved higher and Treasuries moved lower amid constructive developments regarding the state of US/China trade negotiations, with tech stocks leading the way as executives from big chipmaker names within the sector went to the White House to discuss the Chinese tech (Huawei ban). The dollar was rangebound as the market looks ahead to this week’s key risk events (as a reminder: EZ flash PMIs, on Wednesday, ECB on Thursday, US Q2 GDP prelim on Friday). The T-plex edged higher going into the US session supported by a tense geopolitical backdrop. Geopolitics was also supporting crude, albeit edging lower during US trading hours, where the UK looks to impose greater maritime security in the Persian Gulf.

* TRADE: Following last week reports that USTR Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary would meet if talks went well over the phone, SCMP stated this morning negotiators are reportedly likely to visit China next week for the first face to face meeting since G20. If they were to meet it would be a positive step towards reducing the trade tensions between the two nations. According to source reports, the arrangements for the meeting came to light after the US announced it would offer exemptions on 110 Chinese products. Further adding to the positive trade tone, source reports stated China is considering a plan to boost its purchases of US Soybeans. Stratfor highlight that it remains unclear how many US agricultural goods will be purchased by China and that there is no evidence China appears willing to soften its negotiating stance. In a possible goodwill gesture from the US side, the White House convened another tech focused meeting, this time with executives from some of the US’s largest chipmakers, with the focus of the meeting on Chinese tech (i.e. regarding the Huawei ban). Separately, and on a somewhat less constructive tone, the WSJ reported that the Trump administration has imposed sanctions on a Chinese company, Zhuhai Zhenrong, for transporting Iranian crude oil in violation of existing sanctions.

* IRAN: UK Foreign Minister Hunt said if Iran continues on this dangerous path, they must accept the price, a larger western military presence along their coastline. Hunt said Iran had no right to board the UK vessel (Stena Impero), which Iran seized on Friday in the Strait of Hormuz, calling it an act of piracy, whilst urging Iran to release both the vessel and its crew. The Foreign Minister added that there is no comparison between the Stena Impero seizure and the UK’s seizure of the Grace 1 vessel in Gibraltar, which was allegedly violating EU sanctions by exporting oil to Syria. The UK is now looking at implementing a European led maritime mission which will seek to compliment US proposals in regard to maritime security. On the US-Iran front, Iran announced that in 2018 it had arrested 17 Iranian individuals accused of being involved in a CIA-lead spy ring, some of whom it said had been sentenced to death. The US later denied the claims; President Trump said the claims were totally false, lies and propaganda in a tweet.

* BOJ’S KURODA: BOJ's Kuroda, speaking at the IMF in Washington, largely stuck to familiar themes. Traders have been eyeing his remarks for some clues about how the Bank, whose next policy meeting is sandwiched between the ECB and Fed meetings (where both of those central banks are expected to loosen policy). Kuroda, once again, took time to highlight global uncertainties, suggesting they will be a key input into BOJ policy. The BOJ governor talked about how the BOJ's brand of negative rates might impact bank profitability if implemented for too long, however, did not see that risk at present. He argued that it might be better to directly affect long-term rates through large-scale asset purchases, hinting that further BOJ yield curve control might be focussed in the 10-year plus sector. On the inflation goal, he said that at this stage it is not necessary to change the 2% inflation goal.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLED 2 TICKS HIGHER AT 127-19: The T-plex ultimately edged higher on Monday, as participants tread carefully ahead of Thursday’s ECB meeting, where speculation is rife on when and how the ECB will provide monetary accommodation. Some constructive headlines from China over the weekend, who reportedly made goodwill gestures in trade negotiations, saw some mild pressure in government debt in the early session, but was later reversed as traders bought the dip. Bidding pressure was complimented by a surprise dip in the Chicago Fed June National Index -0.02 (exp. 0.08), as well as the overhang of geopolitics. At settlement yields were modestly negative, with the belly seeing the most pronounced action, the 5-year yield fell by just under 2bps.

* WTI FUTURES (U9) SETTLE USD 0.59 HIGHER AT USD 56.22/BBL; BRENT FUTURES (U9) SETTLE USD 0.79 HIGHER AT USD 63.26/BBL: Crude prices, albeit firmer on the day amid tensions in the Persian Gulf, have been drifting lower through the US session in a similar manner to last week’s trading sessions. Iran seizing a UK shipping vessel on Friday helped the major benchmarks start the week on the front foot, as traders factored in a greater geopolitical risk premium. Gains have been modest though, with analysts at RBC noting that participants are not fully realising the severity of the risk of war in the world’s most prolific region of crude supply, and goes on to say that oil prices are a “broken barometer” in gauging risk in the region. RBC propose that USD 80/bbl in Brent could be a possibility if a “shooting war” was to break out. Elsewhere, supply disruption in Libya has has eased after a force majeure, which had been in place since Friday, was lifted at its pinnacle El Sharara oilfield (300k BPD), due to what is widely believed to be sabotage, and later reports suggested the Zawiya refinery (120k BPD) will be shut for two weeks due to power issues. August WTI futures expire on Monday and are likely to be a contributing factor to trade flow due to book squaring, analysts at Citigroup highlight. Looking ahead to this week’s US energy inventories, current expectations have crude stocks drawing 3.4mln bbls, gasoline drawing 0.8mln bbls, and distillates building 1mln bbls.

* S&P 500 0.3% at 2985, NASDAQ-10 0.9% at 7905, Dow Jones  0.1% at 27173, SECTORS: S&P 500 Consumer Discretionary 0.2%, S&P 500 Consumer Staples -0.5%, S&P 500 Energy 0.4%, S&P 500 Financials 0.2%, S&P 500 Health Care -0.2%, S&P 500 Industrials 0.1%, S&P 500 Information Technology 1.2%, S&P 500 Materials -0.3%, S&P 500 Telecommunication Services 0.2%, S&P 500 Utilities -0.2%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Tech was the outperforming sector on Monday, as chipmakers rallied as White House officials agreed to meet tech executives regarding the recent Huawei ban. Applied Materials Inc. (AMAT), Micron Technology (MU), Lam Research (LRCX) and KLA-Tencor Corp. (KLAC) all caught a bid after Goldman turned positive on memory chip makers helping the tech sector, too. Facebook (FB) shares were supported initially by positive comments at Wedbush and saw further upside later in the session on reports the co. had agreed to a USD 5bn FTC settlement, a better outcome than some investors had feared. Meanwhile, Amazon (AMZN) was supported by a sizeable PT raise at KeyBanc and Apple (AAPL) supported by positive comments from Morgan Stanley ahead of earnings.  Elsewhere, Disney (DIS) was buoyant, after its live action remake of the Lion King exceeded expectations over the weekend. Ford (F) were weighed by reports sales in China will fall 27% in H2 2019 Y/Y, amid a downturn in the Chinese car market. AT&T (T) and CBS Corp (CBS) were both under pressure on news that the two companies failed to renew their contract, which will see millions of DirecTV subscribers lose access to CBS programmes. DaVita Inc. (DVA) shot higher after the co. raised its FY19 operating guidance. Bunge Ltd (BG) moved higher premarket on the news the co. has agreed to form a new bioenergy company with BP Plc (BP LN), which will produce ethanol and sugar, while also generating renewable electricity. Notable stocks benefitting after positive broker moves; Charles Schwab (SCHW) upgraded at Well Fargo, Hershey (HSY) upgraded at UBS. Notable stocks suffering after broker downgrades; Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) downgraded at Citi, LyondellBasell (LYB) downgraded at Nomura Instinet, M&T Bank (MTB) downgraded at Piper Jaffray. It was a thin day for large cap earnings; Halliburton Co. (HAL) shot higher after exceeding bottom-line expectations.

* FX WRAP: USD was uninspired ahead of key risk events/data points later this week on both sides of the pond; DXY traded in thin ranges, caught between 97.13-97.29 parameters. EUR was also flat, as traders look ahead to the ECB on Thursday. Political concerns look set to continue weighing on the single currency (Italian election risk has now been joined by growing Spanish election risk; as Spanish PM Sanchez wrangles to form a new government with reluctant ally Podemos). Combined this with the possibility that the ECB could actually pull the trigger on rates this Thursday (markets are pricing a roughly 50% chance of a 10bps deposit rate cut), it comes as no surprise to see CHF continue to strengthen; EURCHF moved as low as 1.10 on the day – NOTE: SocGen last week suggested the closer EURCHF gets to 1.10, the higher the probability that the SNB will act. JPY felt less love after Japanese PM Abe’s upper house election victory stoked risk appetite during APAC hours, seeing USDJPY pop briefly back above 108.00. GBP was under pressure, perhaps unsurprisingly, ahead of frontrunner Boris Johnson’s almost inevitable conservative leadership election victory, which will likely be followed by a slew of government resignations (with the replacements likely to take a tougher stance on the EU). The Scandi Crowns both gradually lost ground, with the moves off 9.6130 and 10.5200 lows in EUR/NOK and EUR/SEK respectively appearing partly technical, although falling oil prices did little to help. On which note; CAD, RUB struggled, with the former also being dragged lower by poor wholesale trade data. Elsewhere in EMFX; ZAR moved back towards recent lows at 13.8100, following news that the SA Government has apportioned more financial aid for Eskom. Conversely, TRY headed back to 5.7000/USD ahead of the Thursday’s CBRT policy meeting; in which anything from a 1% to 5% ease is touted and, all the while, US President Trump is still mulling sanctions.

subject: RBC on oil and Iran: Prices not reflecting the severity of the Persian Gulf tensions
content:
• The "modest" price rise on Friday, due to the seizing of the British ship, is not a severe enough reflection of risks in the region, according to RBC, who believe therefore that oil prices have become a "broken barometer" for gauging risk in the region.
  • The bank don't believe rising US supply could offset the supply disruption from a military intervention ("shooting war") in Iran, suggesting that USD 80/bbl could be the new USD 100/bbl as a geopolitical risk ceiling price.
  • It argues that although both Washington and Tehran would prefer no war, there are red lines which could make an escalation inevitable: 1) casualties of US military personnel 2) Iran further progressing to becoming a couple of months away from being able to assemble a crude nuclear device 3) a mass casualty attack on a US ally in the region. RBC note how currently, escalations have been small and calculated to avoid a big escalation.
  • RBC say Iran may resolve to more aggressive measures if the US does not provide it with economic relief (which could come in the form of oil export waivers). Atlantic Council suggests Iran needs to export approximately 720k BPD to avoid social unrest before the 2020 US elections, so it can continue food and medicine imports. 720k BPD could therefore stand as the entry price for a temporary truce, RBC notes.

BoJ's Kuroda says it is not easy to continue powerful measures for a long time; says powerful monetary easing has boosted demand by lowering real interest rates, but it is taking time to overcome low inflation
content:
• says uncertainties regarding to the global economy have been increasing and some nervousness has been seen in financial markets
  • says BoJ needs to pay close attention to effects of global uncertainty on Japanese economic activity and prices
  • says BoJ will carefully examine various risks and weigh the benefits and costs of its policies
  • says that even in the face of a decline in the natural rate of interest, it is possible to realize accommodative financial conditions, stimulate economic activity
  • says we need to remember that it may take time to overcome entrenched low inflation, even with powerful monetary easing
  • says excessively low rates could make financial institutions reluctant to lend, such as through capital constraints which would diminish the effect of monetary easing

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Loonie and Franc swap sides across the G10 divide
content:
CAD/CHF/EUR

Against the broad trend of relatively rangebound trade awaiting this week’s major events, the Loonie has been undermined by significantly weaker than expected Canadian wholesale trade data and a downturn in oil prices after the latest flare up in the Strait of Hormuz that prompted a crude spike. Usd/Cad has rebounded from just under 1.3050 towards 1.3110, in contrast to Usd/Chf that has inched closer 0.9800, albeit amidst wider Franc strength as Eur/Chf tests 1.1000 and lowest levels for some 2 years. The rationale is partly heightened anticipation that the ECB could actually pull the trigger on rates this Thursday rather than tee the market up for easing in September, with odds between a 10 bp depo cut and no change roughly even, while Italian political jitters are ongoing as Spain begins the task of forming a new Government under Sanchez. Hence, Eur/Usd remains heavy on the 1.1200 handle, with Wednesday’s flash Eurozone PMIs also in focus after a rather bleak Bundesbank monthly report (German GDP to contract in Q2 and no export recovery seen at present).

JPY/GBP/NOK/SEK

The other G10 underperformers as the Yen eased back from circa 107.71 safe-haven highs to just shy of 108.00 ahead of the July BoJ policy meeting that culminates just a day before the FOMC and a speech from Governor Kuroda shortly, while UK political uncertainty and Brexit repercussions continue to weigh on Sterling as Cable dipped under last Friday’s lows but pared some losses after 1.2450 held, and held above 0.9000 vs the Euro, just. Elsewhere, the Scandi Crowns both gradually lost ground and on top of the aforementioned retreat in oil prices amidst Middle East tensions, the moves off 9.6130 and 10.5200 lows in Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek respectively were partly technical.

NZD/AUD

The Kiwi has consolidated gains between 0.6786-58 and 1.0422-1.0387 bands against its US and Aussie counterparts respectively, as the DXY remains constrained in a 97.292-126 range ahead of this week’s preliminary Markit PMIs, the ECB and Fed at the end of the month. Meanwhile, Aud/Usd is pivoting 0.7050 and eyeing RBA speakers for more independent direction given Deputy Government Kent on the agenda tonight and his boss Lowe scheduled later this week.

EM

Contrasting fortunes for the Rand and Lira as Usd/Zar sits near the base of 13.8320-13.9725 parameters following news that the SA Government has apportioned more financial aid for Eskom, but Usd/Try hovers closer to 5.6925 highs than 5.6495 lows ahead of the Thursday’s CBRT policy meeting when anything from a 1% to 5% ease is touted and with US President Trump still mulling sanctions even though Turkey’s Foreign Ministry believes he personally does not wish to implement any more over the Russian S-400 missile platform.

subject: Analysts are watching Rhine water levels for read on how it impacts German industrial output
content:
• The River Rhine through Germany is a vital access point for carrying trade and goods deep to the inland. S&P Global highlights if the water levels fall below 100cm, barges are unable to fully load; levels are expected to fall to around 145cm on Tuesday. UBS note the current levels of 155cm are actually slightly higher than usual. Nonetheless, barge capacity has been limited and is now at just 64%, lower than the 72% in the tail of last week.
  • S&P note when barges cannot unload it usually results in an oversupply of imported petrochemicals, such as methane in the Amsterdam, Rotterdam and Antwerp port hubs, due to increased difficulty taking it further inland.
  • Last year the drought in Germany resulted in the Rhine becoming inaccessible for weeks hurt put Germany’s output, particularly industrial production. This resulted in an action plan to help counter the potential bottleneck, which includes higher storage capacities along the river, the use of lighter ships which enables easier traveling across the river.
  • German’s weather warnings do suggest the summer will see another heatwave, which may worsen the situation.

RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 22nd July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has been increasing control over its supply chain while also expanding its supplier base to bargaining chips in price negotiations, reported DigiTimes. Elsewhere, Morgan Stanley analyst Katy Huberty commented that Apple shares are attractive at current valuations ahead of earnings and increased her price target to USD 247 from USD 231 whilst maintaining an Overweight rating on the stock.
  • The Walt Disney Company’s (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) remake of “The Lion King” topped the weekend’s box office, grossing USD 185mln in North America alone. Meanwhile, Disney’s “Avengers: Endgame” became the highest box office grossing film of all-time, surpassing “Avatar”.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) – The FTC has finalised a settlement with Google in its investigation of YouTube for the alleged violation of federal data privacy laws for kids, reported WaPo.
  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) has announced plans to expands operations in Ohio; the co. will create two new robotic fulfilment centres, creating more than 2500 full-time jobs in the region. Separately, the co. had its price target raised to USD 2,200 from USD 2,100 at KeyBanc; analyst Edward Yruma believes trends have improved since the Q1 and given higher estimates for US retail, noting that Amazon's Fifth Annual Prime Day was the biggest in the company’s history and largely avoided technical difficulties.
  • Applied Materials Inc. (AMAT) (Information Technology/Semiconductor Equipment) has been upgraded to Conviction Buy from Neutral at Goldman Sachs and has been added to the firm's Conviction List; analyst Toshiya Hari believes that meaningful capex cuts, coupled with recent supply-side disruptions, will result in an improvement in memory chip supply & demand sooner than previously expected. Hari upgraded Lam Research (LRCX) (Information Technology/Semiconductor Equipment) to Buy from Neutral and raised his rating on KLA-Tencor Corp. (KLAC) (Information Technology/Semiconductor Equipment) to Neutral from Sell for similar reasons.
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) - Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter anticipates Facebook’s Q2 revenue to come in in-line with or above his estimate but adds that EPS will likely be impacted by a recent FTC settlement charge. The analyst expects Facebook to continue its rapid growth overseas and to increase monetization of under-penetrated Instagram, WhatsApp, and Messenger. He maintains an Outperform rating and a price target of USD 220 on the co.’s share price.
  • Micron Technology (MU) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) has been upgraded to Buy from Neutral and had its target price raised to USD 56 from USD 40 at. Goldman Sachs analyst Mark Delaney commented that the that he believes the excess inventories that memory companies currently have in stock will be depleted faster than expected, primarily in NAND flash; due to Toshiba Memory Corporation’s production outage that has disrupted a mid-single digit percentage of annual industry production.
  • Netflix Inc. (NFLX) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) has signed an agreement with the Screen Actors Guild - American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (SAG-AFTRA), with the contract covering live-action productions, the first deal of its type between the union and the streaming service. Elsewhere, the co. has been threatened with legal action over its Cambridge Analytica documentary, "the Great Hack".
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) has been downgraded to Neutral from Buy at Roth Capital; analyst Craig Irwin believes the electric automaker has a viable path to meet at least the low end of its 360,000-400,000 deliveries guidance for 2019, however, margin risks from rising 2019 battery costs and the impact of increased competition remain.

S&P 500

  • AT&T Inc. (T) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) is dropping CBS channels from cable systems, after the two companies failed to renew their contract. As a result, millions of DirecTV subscribers will lose access to CBS programmes.
  • DaVita Inc. (DVA) (Health Care/Health Care Facilities) has raised its FY19 operating income view to USD 1.64bln-1.7bln from USD 1.54bln-1.64bln; the majority of the increase is a result of improved profit expectations from calcimimetics.
  • Equifax Inc. (EFX) (Industrials/Research & Consulting Services) is set to pay a USD 700mln settlement to end various probes of its 2017 data breach, which compromised the data of nearly 150mln US citizens.
  • Ford Motor (F) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) sales in China have fallen 27% in H2 2019 Y/Y, amid a downturn in the Chinese car market. Separately, the co. will lay off 185 employees at its Ontario plant.
  • Halliburton Co. (HAL) (Energy/Oil & Gas Equipment & Services) (USD) report Q2 19 EPS 0.35 (exp. 0.30), revenue 5.9bln (exp. 5.98bln), momentum is building internationally, and activity improvement should continue into 2020.
  • Lockheed Martin Corp. (LMT) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) has been awarded a USD 1.47bln modification to a previously awarded terminal high-altitude area defence (THAAD) contract with the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. The value of this contract has increased from USD 3.89bln to USD 5.36bln. 
  • Whirlpool Corp. (WHR) (Consumer Discretionary/Household Appliances) is recalling half a million fire-risk tumble dryers, following intervention by the Office for Product Safety and Standards (OPSS).

OTHER

  • Biohaven Pharmaceutical Holding Co Ltd (BHVN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced on Friday that the FDA had opted not to approve its treatment for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease.
  • Bunge Ltd (BG) (Consumer Staples/Food Products) has said it has agreed to form a new bioenergy company with BP Plc (BP LN), which will produce ethanol and sugar, while also generating renewable electricity.
  • Philips (PHIA NA) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment & Supplies) (EUR) reports Q2 revenue 4.7bln (exp. 4.65bln), adj. EBITA 776mln (exp. 542mln), adj. net  260mln (prev. 186mln). Co. affirms SSS and adj. EBITDA margin guidance.
  • Vail Resorts (MTN) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & Leisure) is set to buy smaller rival Peak Resorts (SKIS) for USD 11 per share, a more than 100% premium on last Friday’s closing price. Vail Resorts will add 17 new ski areas to its portfolio.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: core bonds firmer and flatter, Buck underpinned
content: Far from top tier, but in the absence of anything else at the usual early NA data slot the National Activity index miss may have prompted a bit more debt buying as Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries all tick up to fresh intraday highs and the curves flatten further. The 10 year German benchmark has now crossed the July 8 high at 173.72, opening the door to 174.00 and Gilts are inching closer to 131.83, at 131.75, while USTs are nudging 127-20 and the corresponding yield is circa 2.03%. However, the DXY is holding close to a marginal new session high of 97.292 largely due to an even weaker piece of Canadian macro news in the shape of wholesale trade that has lifted Usd/Cad back over 1.3050 and towards 1.3085.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 22nd July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • WTI and Brent futures extend on gains as tensions rise in the Strait of Hormuz
  • Major European indices are relatively flat [Eurostoxx 50 +0.1%], energy sector outperforms on price action in crude markets
  • DXY has consolidated recovery gains above the 97.000 handle, NZD, CAD and AUD outperform
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US National Activity Index, BoJ’s Kuroda

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly lower with the region cautious amid dampened hopes for a more aggressive Fed rate cut and geopolitical concerns after Iran seized 2 UK tankers. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) were both subdued at the open although strength in commodity-related stocks briefly spurred a rebound in Australia, while the Japanese benchmark failed to take advantage of a weaker currency as participants reflected on the Upper House election results in which PM Abe’s ruling coalition won a majority of seats but failed to retain the supermajority needed to push ahead with revising the constitution. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.3%) and Hang Seng (-1.5%) declined despite continued liquidity efforts by the PBoC and more constructive language regarding US-China trade talks, with a rotation of funds seen into China’s new Nasdaq-style tech board known as the STAR Market which launched today and saw all of its 25 stocks surge by an average 126% in early trade and with some higher by more than 200%. Finally, 10yr JGBs were steady with only minimal support seen from the lacklustre tone in stocks and BoJ presence for JPY 1.265tln of JGBs mostly in 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC injected CNY 50bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8759 (Prev. 6.8635)

China Global Times Editor tweeted the Chinese side sees a face-to-face meeting with the US as not far away and expects "actions" may happen soon which would be a sign of goodwill from both sides. In related news, China is reportedly mulling a plan to boost US soybean purchases, according to sources. (Newswires/Twitter)

Hong Kong Police fired tear gas and rubber bullets as protesters took to the streets for a 7th week, while there were reports of hundreds of armed pro-Beijing men attacking protesters, journalists and lawmakers. (Newswires)

Japan's ruling LDP-led coalition won a majority of the seats up for grabs in Sunday's upper house election in which they won 71 of the 124 seats up for contention, although failed to hold on to the two-thirds supermajority needed to move ahead with revising the constitution. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump administration and lawmakers are said to be approaching a deal regarding budget caps and debt ceiling while they await President Trump's approval. (Newswires)

Iran said it has dismantled CIA ring and arrested 17 people with some sentenced to death. Iranian State Media says those suspected of spying for the CIA were arrested during the Iranian calendar year which ended in March 2019. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Hammond will hand his resignation to Theresa May on Wednesday afternoon if, as expected, Mr Johnson is confirmed as Tory leader. (Telegraph)

EU countries are reportedly secretly wooing PM candidate Boris Johnson and signalled an intention to work out a deal to avoid a no-deal disaster. In related news, EU is to prepare an aid package for Ireland to soften no-deal Brexit. (Sunday Times/The Times) US President Trump said he spoke with UK PM candidate Johnson and looks forward to working with him and thinks he will work out Brexit, while there were also reports that Trump expressed concerns with France’s Macron regarding the proposed digital services tax. (Newswires)

 

UK's NIESR sees 2019 GDP growth at +1.2% and 2020 at +1.1% assuming a no-deal Brexit is avoided. (Newswires)

Acting Spanish PM Sanchez will head to Parliament today to seek support in his attempt to form a government. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are relatively flat [Eurostoxx 50 +0.1%], albeit near highs of the day following on from a cautious Asia-Pac trade. Sectors are mixed with outperformance seen in the energy sector amid the price action in the complex. In terms of individual movers, Philips (+4.0%) shares rose on the back of optimistic earnings whilst Julius Baer (+2.7%) shares are supported by an 8% in assets under management.

FX

DXY - The index has consolidated recovery gains above the 97.000 handle within a relatively tight 97.126-247 range following the final official Fed rhetoric ahead of the pre-FOMC backout period from Bullard who reiterated his preference for a 25 bp cut instead of anything larger. Meanwhile, WSJ sources chimed in with similar ‘guidance’ as recent economic developments do not suggest an imminent downturn that would warrant bolder action, although more easy could be flagged after July, and current market pricing reflects the latest commentary with less than 20% chance of a 50 bp ease.

NZD/CAD/AUD - The non-US Dollars are outperforming or at least holding up better than G10 peers, with the Kiwi leading the way on favourable cross-winds as Aud/Nzd retreats through 1.0400 and Nzd/Usd holds nearer last week’s peaks than Aud/Usd between 0.6782-58 and 0.7047-32 respective bands. From a fundamental perspective, the Aussie may glean fresh direction from RBA Assistant Governor Kent later, while the Loonie will be watching Canadian wholesale trade alongside crude prices that are currently supportive and nudging Usd/Cad down through 1.3050 within 1.3068-41 parameters.

GBP/JPY/CHF/EUR - All on the backfoot vs the Greenback, and the Pound in particular awaiting the Tory leadership result that is widely expected to see Brexit hard-liner Boris Johnson appointed as new PM and fresh Cabinet faces before the whole process of negotiating with the EU really starts again. Cable is back below 1.2500 and from a chart standpoint looking more bearish as it slips beneath last Friday’s 1.2476 base. Next up would be July 18’s 1.2429 session low, but Sterling is keeping its head just above 0.9000 vs the Euro that is only just maintaining 1.1200+ status vs the Buck ahead of preliminary PMIs on Wednesday and the ECB on Thursday. Note, the probability of a 10 bp reduction in the depo rate is 50%, while some are also looking for the QE taps to be reopened, albeit not this month. Elsewhere, the Franc is hovering just below 0.9800 and 1.0100 vs the single currency, wary that any ECB stimulus or more pronounced safe-haven gains will be countered by the SNB in some shape or form. Similarly, with this month’s BoJ policy meeting looming on the eve of the FOMC the Yen is erring towards the side of caution closer to 108.00 compared to recent highs and unlikely at this stage to arouse decent option interest sitting from 107.50 to 107.35 in 2.3 bn).

EM - The Lira has Central Bank action to look forward to as well, but US sanctions may be back on the radar to undermine sentiment given reports that President Trump is scheduling a meeting with Republican Senators to discuss options. Meanwhile, the consensus range is suitably wide for the CBRT as estimates cover a whopping 100-500 bp easing, and Usd/Try is near the top of a 5.6925-6490 at present.

 

FIXED INCOME

It’s been measured and slow, but steadfast all the same, as Bunds and Gilts continue to claw back losses from the depths of mid-month retracement lows. In fact, it would be fair to say that the latest leg has been impressive given moves in US Treasuries that lag, with the 10 year EU debt futures up to 173.68 and 131.75 vs 171.25 and 130.14 on July 12. Indeed, the benchmarks are now only a fraction off resistance at 173.70 and 131.83 that stand in the way of big figures, with Independence Day contract peaks not far if those psychological levels are breached (174.05 and 132.45). ECB and Brexit could be the major factors, while USTs are tempering Fed expectations towards 25 bp and the curve may be flattening to make room for supply ahead of 2, 5 and 7 year auctions.

 

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are on the rise as sentiment in the complex is underpinned amid late-Friday reports that the IRGC seized a UK tanker in the Strait of Hormuz due to an alleged violation of maritime law. Meanwhile, UK Chancellor Hammond noted that the UK has been working closely with US and EU partners regarding a response to Iran’s actions. Energy markets are particularly sensitive to developments in the Strait of Hormuz, given that a fifth of the world’s oil exports passes through the corridor everyday whilst  geopolitical tensions intensifies in the area. WTI and Brent futures have tested 57/bbl and 64/bbl to the upside as a result, albeit failed to convincingly breach the levels. Also of note; on Friday Libya’s NOC announced a force majeure at its El-Sharara (300k BPD) oilfield, although this has now been lifted, according to a statement. Elsewhere, spot gold remains within a narrow range amid an uneventful USD and heading into a key meeting for the ECB, in which markets are pricing in a 50% chance of a 10bps cut to its Deposit rate. Meanwhile, copper prices are marginally softer amid the overall cautious risk tone whilst Dalian iron ore prices declined as port inventory across China rose to over 1-month highs.

Force majeure has been lifted on Libya’s El-Sharara oil field (~300k BPD). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS 

Iranian lawmakers filed a motion asking govt to impose toll on ships passing through Strait of Hormuz. (Newswires)

Turkey's Foreign Ministers says that there is uncertainty surrounding US sanction regarding the S-400 deal, adds that US President Trump does not want to impose them, does not expect the US to impose CAATSA sanctions over S-400 deal. (Newswires)

content: The 10 year German benchmark has drifted a bit further from last week’s peaks (173.63) with near term technical resistance around 173.70 still guarding 174.00 and the 174.05 contract high set just a few days before (July 4 and 8 respectively). A pull-back in US Treasuries on latest Fed speak pushing back on prospects for a 50 bp ease at the end of the month has contributed to the downside pressure on core debt, but ahead of next week’s FOMC flash Eurozone and US PMIs, supply and the ECB will likely provide the next drivers. For today, the Bbk monthly bulletin may prompt some reaction, while back to the charts 173.57 and 173.16 form nearest upside and downside targets beyond the 173.43-29 Eurex range so far.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

22nd July 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly lower with the region cautious amid dampened hopes for a more aggressive Fed rate cut and geopolitical concerns after Iran seized 2 UK tankers. ASX 200 (-0.3) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) were both subdued at the open although strength in commodity-related stocks briefly spurred a rebound in Australia, while the Japanese benchmark failed to take advantage of a weaker currency as participants reflected on the Upper House election results in which PM Abe’s ruling coalition won a majority of seats but failed to retain the supermajority needed to push ahead with revising the constitution. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) and Hang Seng (-0.8%) declined despite continued liquidity efforts by the PBoC and more constructive language regarding US-China trade talks, with a rotation of funds seen into China’s new Nasdaq-style tech board known as the STAR Market which launched today and saw all of its 25 stocks surge by an average 126% in early trade and with some higher by more than 200%. Finally, 10yr JGBs were steady with only minimal support seen from the lacklustre tone in stocks and BoJ presence for JPY 1.265tln of JGBs mostly in 1yr-10yr maturities.

FTSE 100

Airline names - UK government is said to consider a carbon surcharge related to airline tickets. Payments would be voluntary but could work on an “opt-out” system. For reference, a fight from London to New York could increase by just under GBP 30. (Times)

Centrica (CPI LN) – Co. is preparing to cut dividend for a second time in four years amid plans for the sale of some oil and gas interests in an attempt to nurse its GBP 2.7bln debt. (Telegraph) 

Metro Bank (MTRO LN) – Co. is reportedly close to a GBP 500mln deal to offload a mortgage portfolio to Cerberus Capital Management. The transaction could be announced at soon as Wednesday, according to Sky News citing sources. (Sky News)

Whitbread (WTB LN) – Jane Street Global Trading is leading a GBP 1.5bln short position against the Co. amid warnings that it is posed for a stock-market sell-off. (Telegraph)

Standard Chartered (STAN LN) – Whistle-blowers have reportedly accused Co. of further transactions with Iran. Separately, Co. board is considering asking CEO Winters to take a pay cut amid pension rows with the largest shareholder, according to sources (FT)

BT (BT/A LN) – Liberty Global (LBTYA) is said to be working on plans with investment bank LionTree for a new venture than could invest billions in full-fibre broadband infrastructure in the UK, in turn increasing pressure on BT to upgrade its network. (Newswires) 

BROKER MOVES

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 22nd July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded mostly lower with the region cautious amid dampened hopes for a more aggressive Fed rate cut and geopolitical concerns
  • Fed officials reportedly could suggest potential for additional stimulus beyond July and signal a 25bp cut is likely at the July meeting
  • IRGC said it seized a UK tanker which has been taken to a coastal area and turned over to the maritime authorities to carry out the necessary legal steps
  • EU countries are reportedly secretly wooing PM candidate Boris Johnson and signalled an intention to work out a deal to avoid a no-deal disaster
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US National Activity Index, BoJ’s Kuroda

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly lower with the region cautious amid dampened hopes for a more aggressive Fed rate cut and geopolitical concerns after Iran seized 2 UK tankers. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) were both subdued at the open although strength in commodity-related stocks briefly spurred a rebound in Australia, while the Japanese benchmark failed to take advantage of a weaker currency as participants reflected on the Upper House election results in which PM Abe’s ruling coalition won a majority of seats but failed to retain the supermajority needed to push ahead with revising the constitution. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) and Hang Seng (-0.8%) declined despite continued liquidity efforts by the PBoC and more constructive language regarding US-China trade talks, with a rotation of funds seen into China’s new Nasdaq-style tech board known as the STAR Market which launched today and saw all of its 25 stocks surge by an average 126% in early trade and with some higher by more than 200%. Finally, 10yr JGBs were steady with only minimal support seen from the lacklustre tone in stocks and BoJ presence for JPY 1.265tln of JGBs mostly in 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC injected CNY 50bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8759 (Prev. 6.8635)

US President Trump said US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin had very good talks with his Chinese counterpart and suggested we'll see what happens. In related news, China Global Times Editor tweeted the Chinese side sees a face-to-face meeting with the US as not far away and expects "actions" may happen soon which would be a sign of goodwill from both sides. (Newswires/Twitter)

 

Hong Kong Police fired tear gas and rubber bullets as protesters took to the streets for a 7th week, while there were reports of hundreds of armed pro-Beijing men attacking protesters, journalists and lawmakers. (Newswires)

 

Japan's ruling LDP-led coalition won a majority of the seats up for grabs in Sunday's upper house election in which they won 71 of the 124 seats up for contention, although failed to hold on to the two-thirds supermajority needed to move ahead with revising the constitution. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Hammond will hand his resignation to Theresa May on Wednesday afternoon if, as expected, Mr Johnson is confirmed as Tory leader. (Telegraph)

 

EU countries are reportedly secretly wooing PM candidate Boris Johnson and signalled an intention to work out a deal to avoid a no-deal disaster. In related news, EU is to prepare an aid package for Ireland to soften no-deal Brexit. (Sunday Times/The Times) US President Trump said he spoke with UK PM candidate Johnson and looks forward to working with him and thinks he will work out Brexit, while there were also reports that Trump expressed concerns with France’s Macron regarding the proposed digital services tax. (Newswires)

 

UK Opposition Leader Corbyn’s popularity among Labour Party members has plummeted, with two fifths wanting him to stand down as leader before the next general election, polling for The Times has found. (Times)

 

Acting Spanish PM Sanchez will head to Parliament today to seek support in his attempt to form a government. (Newswires)

 

Fitch affirmed Germany at AAA; Outlook Stable. S&P affirmed Czech Republic at AA; Outlook Stable. (Newswires) 

FX

 

DXY remained firm and marginally extended on Friday’s rebound back above 97.00 as hopes for a 50bps Fed move faded with CME Fed Fund Futures pricing in just 22.5% chance for a 50bps cut next week. This followed reports that officials aren’t prepared for bolder action of a 50bps cut as recent economic developments have not suggested an imminent downturn, while Fed’s Bullard also reiterated his call for a 25bps cut and doesn't think the situation calls for a larger cut. As such, the greenback’s major counterparts were lacklustre with EUR/USD near the bottom-end of the 1.1200 handle, while GBP/USD struggled to stay above 1.2500 ahead of tomorrow’s leadership announcement and amid concerns regarding front runner Boris Johnson’s “do or die” Brexit attitude, although there were also reports that EU countries are attempting to woo the hardliner and signalled an intention to work out a deal to avert a disaster. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were higher on a concerted attempt on the next round numbers to the upside despite the cautious risk tone, while antipodeans were constrained due to their high-beta properties. 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures higher overnight and back above the USD 56.00/bbl level as prices were lifted by the geopolitical risk premium following the Iran seizure of a British tanker in the Strait of Hormuz, while a decline in the latest US Baker Hughes rig numbers and production outages at Libya’s El Sharara oil field added to the bullish factors for crude. Elsewhere, gold was subdued near Friday’s lows amid a firm greenback due to reduced hopes for more aggressive action at next week’s FOMC and copper also languished overnight as price action reflected the broad cautious risk tone.

Baker Hughes (July 19th): Oil rigs -5 at 779, Gas rigs +2 at 174, Total rigs -4 at 954. (Newswires)

Libya’s NOC confirmed 290k bpd output at Sharara had been offline since Friday. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

IRGC said it seized a UK tanker which has been taken to a coastal area and turned over to the maritime authorities to carry out the necessary legal steps, while Iran later confirmed the seizure of a second UK tanker which was let off with a warning about violating maritime regulations. (Newswires)

UK called an emergency committee meeting in response to the vessels seizure and ministers are planning to place sanctions on Iran. In related news, the White House stated the NSC will continue to work with its allies and partners to defend against Iran’s "malign behaviour", while the US also confirmed it will deploy forces to Saudi Arabia and increase maritime surveillance in the Arabian Gulf. (Newswires)

US President Trump reportedly told Senator Rand Paul he would like to be involved in Iran talks, after Senator Rand Paul was said to have met with Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif to discuss the potential prospects for talks between US and Iran. In related news, US Secretary of State Pompeo said President Trump is prepared to conduct talks with Iran without preconditions and that we need the Iranians to come to the table for negotiations. (Newswires)

Iranian lawmakers filed a motion asking govt to impose toll on ships passing through Strait of Hormuz. (Newswires)

Trump administration invited Republican Senators to a meeting to discuss the potential sanctions on Turkey. (WaPo)

 

US

The T-plex got off on the backfoot into Friday’s European session as the market pared back the dovish reaction from Fed’s Williams on Thursday. Although support was provided on the back of some disappointing German PPI data, where the Bund strength spread into wider government bonds. A mixed July (prelim.) University of Michigan survey didn’t cause a stir. Later in the US session, there was some further selling as Fed’s Bullard affirmed his preference to a 25bps rate cut at the July meeting, which was then echoed by Fed sources claiming that the general sentiment among Fed members was also for a 25bps cut. However, news of British shipping vessels being seized in the Persian Gulf saw bidding into the settlement, at which, the curve had flattened, seeing the 2s10s narrowing by approximately 3.5bps. US T-note futures (U9) settled 3+ ticks lower at 127-17.

Fed officials reportedly could suggest potential for additional stimulus beyond July and signal a 25bp cut is likely at the July meeting. Furthermore, the article states officials aren’t prepared for bolder action by making a half-point cut as recent economic developments have not pointed to an imminent downturn. (WSJ)

Fed's Bullard (Voter, Dove) reiterated call for a 25bps cut at the July meeting and said a 25bps cut would give the Fed the option for a cut later in the year. Bullard also noted it would be difficult for the Fed not to ease at this point and would have to follow through on rate cuts to ratify earlier policy signals, while he sees no reason to revisit decision on timing of balance sheet runoff and would like to see a new repo facility made available but added the Fed is not at that point just yet. Furthermore, Bullard said he would listen to arguments for a larger rate cut but thinks 25bps is appropriate and doesn't think the situation calls for a larger cut. (Newswires/WSJ)

US President Trump administration and lawmakers are said to be approaching a deal regarding budget caps and debt ceiling while they await President Trump's approval. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks begin the week downbeat amid Iran concerns, dampened hopes for a larger Fed cut and with China underperforming as funds shift into its newly-launched Nasdaq-style tech board
content:
Asia equity markets trade mostly lower with the region cautious following a quiet weekend in terms of newsflow and last Friday’s losses on Wall St. where geopolitical concerns weighed on sentiment after Iran seized 2 UK tankers. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) were both subdued at the open although strength in commodity-related stocks briefly spurred a rebound in Australia, while the Japanese benchmark fails to take advantage of a weaker currency as participants reflect on the Upper House election results in which PM Abe’s ruling coalition won a majority of seats but failed to retain the supermajority needed to push ahead with revising the constitution. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.9%) and Hang Seng (-0.8%) underperform despite continued liquidity efforts by the PBoC and more constructive language regarding US-China trade talks, amid a rotation of funds into China’s new Nasdaq-style tech board known as the STAR Market which launched today and saw all of its 25 stocks surge by an average 126% in early trade and with some higher by more than 200%.

In FX markets, the DXY remains firm and marginally extends on Friday’s rebound back above the 97.00 level as hopes for a 50bps Fed move faded with CME Fed Fund Futures pricing in just 22.5% chance for a 50bps cut next week. This followed reports that officials aren’t prepared for bolder action of a 50bps cut as recent economic developments have not signalled an imminent downturn, while Fed’s Bullard also reiterated his call for a 25bps cut and doesn't think the situation calls for a larger cut. As such, the greenback’s major counterparts are lacklustre with EUR/USD near the bottom-end of the 1.1200 handle, while GBP/USD struggles to stay above 1.2500 ahead of tomorrow’s leadership announcement and amid concerns regarding front runner Boris Johnson’s “do or die” Brexit attitude, although there were also reports that EU countries are attempting to woo the hardliner and signalled an intention to work out a deal to avert a disaster. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are higher on a concerted attempt on the next round numbers to the upside despite the cautious risk tone, while antipodeans are constrained due to their high-beta properties.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are steady with only minimal gains seen despite the mostly lacklustre tone in stocks and BoJ presence for JPY 1.265tln of JGBs mostly in 1yr-10yr maturities.
